Complex eigen{vectors,values}
We've done distinct real, now we do complex (later repeated roots...)

Let $A$ be the matrix in $\mathbb{R}^{2\times2}$ as expected.
The characteristic  $p(\lambda) = \det(A - \lambda I) = \lambda^2 - tr(A) + \det(A)$.
$tr$ is the trace of the matrix; that is, the sum of the diagonal elements.

Cf. wksht #$19$

We use essentially the same technique, using the fact that $p(\lambda) = 0$ and then flipping the top row and inverting the sign of $A - \lambda I$.

That is, we have pairs $\lambda_i \in \mathbb{C}, v_i \in \mathbb{C}^{2\times1}$. These $v_i$ actually take the form $u + iv$.

We can also show readily that all $v_i$ are orthogonal (regardless of which space they are in)! They are essentially rotations of the coordinate space.

For real $\lambda,v$, we use solutions of the form $ce^{\lambda t}v$.

This works for complex $\lambda,v$ also! $ce^{\lambda t}(u\pm iv)$ (since they come in complex-conjugate pairs: $\lambda = \alpha \pm \beta i$).

We compute one of the pair-solutions (simply ignore the sign differences) and their real/imaginary parts $\Re,\Im$. This is $Y_{\Re} + i Y_{\Im}$ solves the ODE $Y' = AY$.

We end up with $e^{\alpha t} [ \cos(\beta t) + i\sin(\beta t) ] [ u + iv ]$ so then
$Y_{\Re} = e^{\alpha t} [ \cos(\beta t)u - \sin(\beta t)v ]$,
$Y_{\Im} = e^{\alpha t} [ \cos(\beta t)v + \sin(\beta t)u ]$.

Then $Y_{\Re} - i Y_{\Im}$ is also a solution, and the full solution is the linear combination
$Y(t) = \matrixstart Y_{\Re} & Y_{\Im} \matrixend(t) \matrixstart c_1 \\ c_2 \matrixend$

Fortunately, at $t=0$ this reduces to $Y(0) = c_1 u + c_2 v = \matrixstart u & v \matrixend \matrixstart c_1 \\ c_2 \matrixend$.

For $A = \matrixstart a & b \\ c & d \matrixend$,

* $A^T = \matrixstart a & c \\ b & d \matrixend$,

* $\bar{A} = \matrixstart a^* & b^* \\ c^* & d^* \matrixend$ (for those elements which have conjugates $x^*$)

* $A^* = \bar{A}^T$

In the more general cases, the $.^T$ operator transposes, or rotates around the diagonal.
$\bar{.}$ is the conjugate operator, and $.^*$ their composition.
